metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Analyse the change in gravitational potential energy from area under a force vs distance graph and area under a field vs distance graph multiplied by mass

uniform_field_formula.name: Uniform Field GPE Formula
uniform_field_formula.correct: In uniform gravitational fields (near Earth's surface), use ΔGPE = mgΔh where g is constant.

ΔGPE = mgh².error: Height is not squared in the GPE formula.
ΔGPE = mgh².fix: ΔGPE = mgΔh. Height appears to the first power only.
ΔGPE = mgh².action: Check: if you double height, GPE should double, not quadruple.

ΔGPE = ½mgΔh.error: No half factor in gravitational PE.
ΔGPE = ½mgΔh.fix: The ½ is for kinetic energy (½mv²), not GPE.
ΔGPE = ½mgΔh.action: Don't confuse GPE = mgΔh with KE = ½mv².

ΔGPE = mg/Δh.error: Wrong operation. It's multiplication, not division.
ΔGPE = mg/Δh.fix: ΔGPE = mg × Δh. All three quantities multiply together.
ΔGPE = mg/Δh.action: Check units: kg × m/s² × m = kg·m²/s² = Joules.

persistent.action: Make a formula card: GPE = mgΔh (no ½, no squares). Practice until automatic.

non_uniform_field_identification.name: Non-Uniform Field Identification
non_uniform_field_identification.correct: In non-uniform fields, g changes significantly with position, so ΔGPE = mgΔh cannot be used directly.

g is constant everywhere.error: Only true very close to Earth's surface.
g is constant everywhere.fix: g = GM/r² means g decreases as you move away from a planet.
g is constant everywhere.action: Calculate g at Earth's surface vs at twice the radius. They differ.

all fields are uniform.error: Uniform fields are an approximation for small height changes.
all fields are uniform.fix: Real gravitational fields follow the inverse square law.
all fields are uniform.action: Near surface = approximately uniform. Far from surface = clearly non-uniform.

uniform fields don't exist.error: Uniform fields are valid approximations near planet surfaces.
uniform fields don't exist.fix: When Δh is small compared to r, treating g as constant works well.
uniform fields don't exist.action: For everyday heights (metres, not thousands of km), uniform is fine.

persistent.gap: You don't understand when to use uniform vs non-uniform models.
persistent.action: Rule: If Δh << r (height much smaller than radius), use uniform. Otherwise, use graphs.

force_distance_graph_area.name: Force-Distance Graph Area
force_distance_graph_area.correct: The area under a force-distance graph equals the change in gravitational potential energy directly.

ΔGPE = gradient of F-r graph.error: Gradient gives rate of change, not energy.
ΔGPE = gradient of F-r graph.fix: Area under curve = work done = ΔGPE. Gradient tells you how force changes.
ΔGPE = gradient of F-r graph.action: Area = F × Δr = N × m = J (energy). Gradient = ΔF/Δr (not energy).

ΔGPE = Area × mass.error: No need to multiply by mass for force-distance graphs.
ΔGPE = Area × mass.fix: Force already includes mass (F = mg). Area gives energy directly.
ΔGPE = Area × mass.action: Compare: F-r graph (area = ΔGPE), g-r graph (area × m = ΔGPE).

ΔGPE = Force × time.fix: Work = Force × distance. Impulse = Force × time.
ΔGPE = Force × time.action: Check the x-axis: distance gives energy, time gives impulse.

persistent.gap: You're confusing what the area under different graphs represents.
persistent.action: Memorise: F × d = energy (Joules). F × t = impulse (N·s). Always check the x-axis.

field_distance_graph_area.name: Field-Distance Graph Area
field_distance_graph_area.correct: The area under a field-distance graph multiplied by mass gives the change in GPE.

ΔGPE = Area under g-r graph.fix: Field-distance area has units J/kg. Multiply by mass to get Joules.
ΔGPE = Area under g-r graph.action: Units: (N/kg) × m = N·m/kg = J/kg. Need × m to get J.

ΔGPE = Area ÷ mass.fix: ΔGPE = Area × mass. Area gives energy per kilogram.
ΔGPE = Area ÷ mass.action: Area = J/kg (energy per unit mass). × mass = total energy.

ΔGPE = gradient of g-r graph.error: Gradient tells you how field strength changes, not energy.
ΔGPE = gradient of g-r graph.fix: Area under the curve gives work done per kg, not gradient.

persistent.action: Practice unit analysis: g-r area = (N/kg)(m) = J/kg. Then × kg = J.

counting_squares_method.name: Counting Squares Method
counting_squares_method.correct: Count squares under the curve, then multiply by the area of one square to find total area.

count only full squares.fix: Include a square if more than half is under the curve, exclude if less than half.
count only full squares.action: For accuracy, count partials: >50% under = include, <50% = exclude.

add up the y-values.fix: Area = base × height. Count squares or use trapezoidal rule.
add up the y-values.action: Area ≠ sum of y-values. Area = integral of y over x range.

multiply x-axis by y-axis values.error: You need to find the area of each square first.
multiply x-axis by y-axis values.fix: Each square has area = (x-spacing) × (y-spacing). Count squares, then multiply.
multiply x-axis by y-axis values.action: Find one square's area from axis scales. Then count total squares.

persistent.gap: You don't understand graphical area calculation.
persistent.action: Practice: draw a curve, count squares, calculate area. Verify with geometry formulas.

trapezoidal_method.name: Trapezoidal Rule
trapezoidal_method.correct: For approximately linear sections, use the trapezoid formula: Area = ½(a + b) × h where a and b are parallel sides.

Area = a × b × h.fix: Trapezoid area = ½(a + b) × h, not a × b × h.
Area = a × b × h.action: Draw a trapezoid. Two parallel sides (a, b), one height (h).

Area = (a + b) × h.fix: Trapezoid = ½(a + b) × h. The ½ is essential.
Area = (a + b) × h.action: Check: trapezoid is half of a parallelogram with sides (a+b) and h.

Area = ½ × a × b.error: That's a triangle formula, and incomplete.
Area = ½ × a × b.fix: Triangle = ½ × base × height. Trapezoid = ½(a + b) × h.
Area = ½ × a × b.action: Trapezoid has two parallel sides. Triangle formula doesn't fit.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise the trapezoid formula.
persistent.action: Write Area = ½(a + b) × h ten times. Identify a, b, h on graphs.

energy_conservation_nonuniform.name: Energy Conservation in Non-Uniform Fields
energy_conservation_nonuniform.correct: In non-uniform fields, energy is still conserved. Falling objects convert GPE to KE, rising objects convert KE to GPE.

energy is not conserved.error: Energy is always conserved in isolated systems.
energy is not conserved.fix: Non-uniform fields still conserve energy. Calculation method differs, not the principle.
energy is not conserved.action: Conservation applies everywhere. Only the formula for GPE changes.

KE = GPE at all times.error: KE and GPE transform into each other, they're not always equal.
KE = GPE at all times.fix: Total mechanical energy is constant. KE + GPE = constant.
KE = GPE at all times.action: At top: high GPE, low KE. At bottom: low GPE, high KE.

only applies near Earth.fix: Conservation works everywhere: near Earth, in space, around other planets.
only applies near Earth.action: The law doesn't change. Only the method of calculating GPE changes.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the calculation method with the physical principle.
persistent.action: Key insight: Energy conservation is universal. Non-uniform fields just need graphs to find ΔGPE.

work_gpe_relationship.name: Work-GPE Relationship
work_gpe_relationship.correct: Work done by gravity equals the change in GPE, which equals the change in KE (when gravity is the only force).

work is different from energy.fix: Work done = energy transferred. Same units (Joules), same quantity.
work is different from energy.action: W = F × d = energy. Work measures energy transfer.

work done = force only.error: Work requires both force AND displacement.
work done = force only.fix: W = F × d. Force alone doesn't define work—distance matters.
work done = force only.action: No displacement = no work, even if large force is applied.

area gives force, not work.error: Area under F-d graph gives work/energy.
area gives force, not work.action: Check units: N × m = J (energy), not N (force).

persistent.gap: You're not connecting work, energy, and graphs.
persistent.action: Chain: Area under F-r graph → Work done → ΔGPE → ΔKE (if only gravity acts).

graph_interpretation.name: Identifying Graph Types
graph_interpretation.correct: Always check the vertical axis: Force (N) means use area directly. Field strength (N/kg) means multiply area by mass.

all graphs work the same.error: Different y-axis quantities require different methods.
all graphs work the same.fix: F-r graph: area = ΔGPE. g-r graph: area × m = ΔGPE.
all graphs work the same.action: First step: read the y-axis label. Force or field strength?

horizontal axis doesn't matter.error: The x-axis must be distance for energy calculations.
horizontal axis doesn't matter.fix: F vs time gives impulse, not energy. F vs distance gives work.
horizontal axis doesn't matter.action: For ΔGPE, x-axis must be distance (m), not time (s).

shape of curve doesn't matter.error: The curve shape determines the area calculation method.
shape of curve doesn't matter.fix: Straight line → triangle/rectangle. Curved → count squares or trapezoid.
shape of curve doesn't matter.action: Choose method based on curve shape: geometry formulas or numerical methods.

persistent.gap: You're not reading graphs carefully before calculating.
persistent.action: Before calculating: 1) Read y-axis label. 2) Read x-axis label. 3) Note the curve shape.

unit_analysis.name: Unit Analysis for Area
unit_analysis.formula: N × m = J, (N/kg) × m × kg = J
unit_analysis.correct: Area units must give Joules. Force-distance gives J directly. Field-distance gives J/kg, needing mass multiplication.

units don't matter.error: Units verify your answer is correct.
units don't matter.fix: Final answer must be in Joules for energy. Check by unit analysis.
units don't matter.action: Before accepting an answer, verify units = kg·m²/s² = J.

N/kg × m = J.fix: (N/kg) × m = J/kg. Need × kg to get J.
N/kg × m = J.action: Full chain: (N/kg) × m × kg = N·m = J.

area is always in Joules.fix: F-r area → J. g-r area → J/kg.
area is always in Joules.action: Check y-axis units: N → area is J. N/kg → area is J/kg.

persistent.gap: You need to track units through calculations.
persistent.action: Write units at every step. Final answer must be Joules for energy.

inverse_square_curve.name: Inverse Square Relationship Shape
inverse_square_curve.correct: Both force and field strength follow inverse square curves that decrease rapidly then level off with distance.

linear decrease.fix: 1/r² curves drop steeply at first, then flatten. Not a straight line.
linear decrease.action: Plot 1/r² for r = 1, 2, 3, 4. Values: 1, 0.25, 0.11, 0.0625. Not linear.

constant value.error: That's only true for uniform fields.
constant value.fix: Non-uniform fields change with distance. Uniform fields don't.
constant value.action: Constant horizontal line = uniform field. Curved line = non-uniform.

increases with distance.fix: g = GM/r² and F = GMm/r² both have r² in denominator. Bigger r → smaller value.
increases with distance.action: Inverse relationship: as r increases, g and F decrease.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the inverse square relationship graphically.
persistent.action: Sketch g vs r for a planet. Steep curve near surface, flattening far away.

scale_factor_awareness.name: Graph Scale Factors
scale_factor_awareness.correct: Always check for scale factors like ×10⁶ on axes. Area calculations must include these factors.

ignore small numbers on axes.error: Those are scale factors that affect your answer.
ignore small numbers on axes.fix: ×10⁶ m means each unit on the axis is 1 million metres.
ignore small numbers on axes.action: Before calculating: note all scale factors on both axes.

scale factors cancel.fix: If x-axis is ×10⁶ and y-axis is ×10², area is × 10⁶ × 10² = ×10⁸.
scale factors cancel.action: Area of one square = (x-scale) × (y-scale). Include in final answer.

only x-axis scale matters.error: Both axes contribute to the area scale.
only x-axis scale matters.fix: Area = width × height. Both need correct scaling.

persistent.gap: You're not accounting for scale factors in area calculations.
persistent.action: Circle all scale factors before starting. Calculate one square's area with full units.
